conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking all non-critical notifications during medical staff work hours, effectively forbidding those notifications, while User Story B requires health reminders (notifications) to follow the older person's preferred timing, which may include times during staff shifts. This creates opposing instructions for the same event of notification delivery.
userStoryASummary: As a medical staff, I want to block all non-critical notifications during my work hours to avoid distractions and focus solely on critical patient health data.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED's health reminders to follow my preferred timing so I can stay independent and avoid feeling frustrated.

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids intrusive notifications and emphasizes respecting privacy and autonomy, effectively forbidding proactive reminders, while User Story B mandates proactive reminders about exercises and health tasks, creating opposing expectations on system behavior when reminding the user.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to encourage clients to do simple exercises and choose healthier meals in a way that respects their privacy and autonomy without intrusive notifications.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person eager to stay motivated, I want ALFRED to proactively remind me about exercises and health tasks to help me maintain my physical and cognitive wellbeing.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires encouraging healthy behaviors while respecting privacy and autonomy without intrusive notifications, implying limitations on data use or sharing. User Story B requires open sharing of all personal health data for personalized support. These impose opposite constraints on data sharing and system operation regarding user privacy, creating a forbid-stop conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to encourage clients to do simple exercises and choose healthier meals in a way that respects their privacy and autonomy without intrusive notifications.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share all my personal health data openly to receive the most personalized support from ALFRED and feel confident in my care.

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids intrusive communication with clients to respect privacy, while User Story B requires spontaneous informal chats during cognitive games, creating opposite expectations on ALFRED's communication behavior under the same context.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver managing multiple clients, I want to communicate with each client only through their preferred channels and avoid intrusive check-ins to respect their privacy and maintain trust.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to have spontaneous, informal chats with me during cognitive games to keep me motivated and engaged.

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids intrusive communication and respects client privacy by limiting communication channels, while User Story B requires open sharing of all personal health data to maximize personalized support; these impose opposite expectations on data sharing and communication behaviors.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver managing multiple clients, I want to communicate with each client only through their preferred channels and avoid intrusive check-ins to respect their privacy and maintain trust.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share all my personal health data openly to receive the most personalized support from ALFRED and feel confident in my care.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires monitoring health data streams only with patient consent (permission needed to start monitoring), while User Story B requires automatic activation of health support and interventions even if it feels controlling (implying no consent needed), creating opposing instructions on when monitoring and interventions should start.
userStoryASummary: As medical staff, I want to monitor all available health data streams with patient consent to support efficient care during shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A requires scheduling video check-ins only with patient consent, effectively forbidding interventions without consent, while User Story B requires ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, implying performing interventions without consent. These impose opposite expectations on system behavior regarding patient consent.
userStoryASummary: As medical staff, I want to schedule video check-ins with patient consent to prioritize health monitoring while respecting privacy.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids non-critical notifications during work hours to avoid distractions, while User Story B requires automatic activation of health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, implying that some alerts or interventions should start regardless of user control, creating opposite expectations on notification behavior under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a medical staff, I want ALFRED to block all non-critical and emotional notifications during my work hours, so I can focus exclusively on urgent patient health data without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A requires manual control to choose which game sessions to record and share, effectively forbidding automatic recording, while User Story B demands automatic activation of health support and interventions, implying automatic system actions without manual consent. These impose opposite expectations on system behavior regarding intervention activation and data sharing.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually choose which cognitive game sessions to record and share to fully respect clients' privacy preferences.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids initiating video calls without client consent to protect privacy, while User Story B requires automatic activation of health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, implying operation initiation without consent. These opposing instructions on initiating interventions upon the same triggering condition constitute a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to initiate video calls only with client consent to protect their privacy and dignity.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A requires that detailed vitals access occurs only with client consent (forbidding access without consent), whereas User Story B mandates automatic activation of health support and interventions regardless of client control, creating opposing instructions on when health data access and interventions should start.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to access detailed vitals and activity reports only when clients have given consent to ensure privacy while providing personalized care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids automatic health data logging and sharing under normal conditions, while User Story B requires automatic activation of health support and interventions, which implies automatic data use. These are opposing instructions triggered by the system's health monitoring event.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to disable automatic health data logging and manually control data sharing to respect client privacy preferences under normal conditions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control and potentially restrict automatic health data logging and sharing to protect privacy, effectively forbidding automatic system actions, while User Story B requires ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, essentially mandating the start of those operations. These opposing instructions on automatic health data handling constitute a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control automatic health data logging and sharing to respect privacy while supporting ongoing care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to automatically activate health support and interventions even if it feels controlling, because I prioritize my health and well-being.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking all non-critical notifications during work hours to focus on essential data, while User Story B forbids almost all notifications about physical exercises, which are a subset of non-critical notifications. The operation of blocking notifications is mandated selectively by one story and broadly forbidden by the other, creating a conflict on when notifications should be blocked.
userStoryASummary: As a medical staff member, I want to block all non-critical notifications during work hours to focus solely on essential clinical data without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to block and dismiss almost all notifications about physical exercises because I find them intrusive, overwhelming, and prefer to avoid challenging activities.
cluster: Minimal and Formal Interaction with ALFRED

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids non-critical notifications during medical staff work hours to avoid distractions, while User Story B requires hydration reminders (a type of notification) only upon explicit request, implying the system should normally send reminders unless explicitly asked not to. Both impose opposing instructions on when hydration reminders (notifications) should be sent.
userStoryASummary: As a medical staff member, I want ALFRED to block all non-critical notifications during my work hours to avoid distractions and focus solely on urgent patient care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive hydration reminders only when I explicitly ask for them, so I can avoid unwanted interruptions and maintain control.
cluster: Minimal and Formal Interaction with ALFRED

conflictDescription: User Story A forbids automatic data logging by requiring manual control over what is recorded, while User Story B expects the system to send hydration reminders only on explicit user request, implying some automatic monitoring or prompting. The opposing instructions on automatic system behavior versus manual control create a Start-Forbid conflict regarding when system operations should be triggered.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to disable automatic data logging and manually select what is recorded to fully control my clients' privacy.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive hydration reminders only when I explicitly ask for them, so I can avoid unwanted interruptions and maintain control.
cluster: Minimal and Formal Interaction with ALFRED
